identificationModule.briefTitle: Non-invasive Vagal Neurostimulation (nVNS) in Adolescents With Postural Orthostatic Tachycardia Syndrome (POTS)
identificationModule.officialTitle: Pilot Study--The Effects of Non-invasive Vagal Neurostimulation (nVNS) in Adolescents With Postural Orthostatic Tachycardia Syndrome (POTS)

descriptionModule.briefSummary: The purpose of this study is to determine if nVNS will decrease autonomic symptom intensity (COMPASS-31 and Child Functional Disability Inventory) in adolescent patients with postural orthostatic tachycardia syndrome (POTS) in comparison to standard recovery STEPS management.
descriptionModule.detailedDescription:
Project purpose: The investigators will study the use of non invasive vagal nerve stimulation in newly diagnosed adolescent patients with POTS to see if symptom management improves over 2 months. Surveys will include COMPASS-31. Child Functional Disability Inventory, and PHQ-9. Patient logs will evaluate headache frequency, exercise duration and VNS use.

Research objectives: The investigators hypothesize that:

Primary Aim 1. Use of noninvasive vagal nerve stimulation will decrease autonomic symptom intensity compared to control group.

Primary Aim 2. Use of noninvasive vagal nerve stimulator will improve child function.

Primary Aim 3. Heart rate elevation measured by head up tilt table test will decrease in the treatment group compared to the control group.

Secondary goals include:

Secondary Aim 1: To determine if utilization of noninvasive vagal nerve stimulation influences headache frequency Secondary Aim 2: Determine if utilization of noninvasive vagal nerve stimulation will influence weekly duration of aerobic exercise.

Secondary Aim 3: Determine if utilization of noninvasive vagal nerve stimulator results in significant side effects, particularly depression, in adolescent patients.

designInfo.interventionModelDescription: Half of the patient population will be randomized to standard management only. The other half of the population will be randomized to standard management plus use of the vagal nerve stimulator

armGroups.label: Standard Postural Orthostatic Tachycardia Syndrome management/ STEPS
armGroups.description: The General Pediatric and Adolescent Medicine providers at Mayo Clinic utilize a specific management program for their patients with Postural Orthostatic Tachycardia Syndrome utilizing the acronym STEPS. S is for liberal intake of salt, T is for drinking 90-100 ounces/day of fluid, E is for slowly and gradually improve continuous aerobic exercise duration to a goal of 50 minute most days of the week, P is for possible utilization of 1 of two prescription medications (metoprolol or midodrine), and S is for setting priorities and goals such as encouraging good sleep hygiene, attendance at school, social interactions, and counseling.

armGroups.label: STEPS + GammaCore Intervention (noninvasive vagal nerve stimulation)
armGroups.description: Utilization of STEPS management goals plus the addition of non invasive vagal nerve stimulators for two 2 minutes of intervention performed three times a day.

interventions.name: GammaCore intervention
interventions.description: Use of the vagal nerve stimulator, GammaCore, on the right side of the neck for two 2 minute stimulations performed 3 times a day
armGroupLabels: STEPS + GammaCore Intervention (noninvasive vagal nerve stimulation)
otherNames: external vagal nerve stimulator, non-invasive vagal nerve stimulator

interventions.name: STEPS management protocol
interventions.description: STEPS is the acronym for the standard management program for our patients with POTS. It includes liberal use of salt, taking in 90-100 ounces of fluid, gradually increasing the duration of aerobic exercise, possible use of one of two prescription medications (metoprolol, and midodrine), and encouragement to set priority and goals

eligibilityModule.eligibilityCriteria:
Inclusion criteria:

1. Patient's age 12-19 years of age
2. Newly diagnosed POTS at Mayo Clinic in Rochester
3. Head up tilt table test results in a heart rate increase of 40 or more bpm
4. Consent is able to be obtained appropriately per age

Exclusion criteria:

1. POTS patients with orthostatic hypotension
2. POTS patients with vasovagal syncope
3. Use of medications other than midodrine or metoprolol
4. Inability to independently utilize the GammaCore device
5. Inability to independently complete surveys or patient logs
6. Patients receiving hormonal therapy other than birth control
7. Pregnancy
8. Prior neck surgery
9. Metallic implant present
10. Cardiac disorder
11. Presence of an eating disorder
12. Use of a feeding tube
